awd_titl_txt: Participant Support for the 23rd American Conference on Crystal Growth and Epitaxy (ACCGE-23); Tucson, Arizona; 13-18 August 2023
awd_abstract_narration:
This grant provides participant support for attendees of the 23rd American Conference on Crystal Growth and Epitaxy (ACCGE-23) to be held in Tucson, Arizona, 13-18 August 2023. The conference focuses on new research and development activities in bulk single crystal and epitaxial thin film growth. Students and faculty present their latest research results on crystal growth and epitaxy through oral and poster sessions. The conference impacts the advanced manufacturing and broader engineering communities. Priority is given to student and young faculty participants who are women or who come from underrepresented minority groups. This approach promotes diverse participation at the conference, in the short term, and in STEM fields, in the long term. This award benefits the nation through the education of a skilled and diverse manufacturing workforce, which is better prepared to provide transformative solutions to the challenges in their chosen fields. The conference plays an important role in supporting and sustaining the important field of crystal growth and epitaxy, which is an important component of semiconductor and microelectronics research. This conference is timely because of renewed interest in the revitalization of microelectronics and semiconductor manufacturing in the US.

This participant support is expected to benefit the students' professional, scientific, and technical development. Attendance at the conference gives the students and faculty a broader view of crystal growth and thin film epitaxy, its fundamentals, advanced manufacturing, advanced characterization, and applications. Symposium topics include fundamentals of materials synthesis, crystal structure analysis, crystal growth techniques and methods, high throughput manufacturing, process modeling, monitoring and control, and specialized topics, such as 2D nanomaterials, ceramics, ferroelectrics, and microfluidic processing. The conference is an opportunity for participants to showcase their scientific accomplishments, interact with peers and colleagues in academia, government labs and industry and extend their network within the broad materials processing and advanced manufacturing communities. Attendees will learn about state-of-the-art research in their technical areas via access to several technical and professional development talks by leading domestic and international speakers. Students and young faculty enhance their communication skills through oral and poster presentations and in-depth discussions of their work with peers in their technical areas. This interactive experience significantly broadens student education, increases their enthusiasm for their research topic, acquaints them with expectations for scientific careers, and exposes them to new approaches for innovative research.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The project provided funds for graduate students and early career participants to attend the 23rd American Conference on Crystal Growth and Epitaxy (ACCGE-23) which was held from August 13-18, 2023.  Continuing a tradition, ACCGE-23 was held in conjunction with the 21st U.S. Workshop on Organometallic Vapor Phase Epitaxy (OMVPE-21). The event in 2023 was organized and hosted by the American Association for Crystal Growth (AACG).

The scientific program of ACCGE-23/OMVPE-21 consisted of 23 topical symposia covering both theoretical and experimental aspects of growth and characterization of semiconducting, oxide, metallic, organic and biological crystals. Five plenary lectures were presented on topics ranging from wide bandgap materials to crystal growth in micro-gravity and commercialization. The technical symposia included approximately 103 invited presentations from researchers representing a broad swath of the field including presentations from industrial researchers focused on process scale-up and manufacturing. An additional 85 contributed presentations and ~20 posters rounded out the technical program.

The ACCGE-23/OMVPE-21 conference was very successful with ~250 on-site participants. This included ~30 student and early career attendees who paid a reduced registration fee. 

Intellectual Merit

Crystal growth has historically occupied an awkward position among the scientific and engineering disciplines. In the condensed matter physics and materials discovery communities, crystal growth and epitaxy are often considered as a means to the production of samples for property measurements.  However, the science and practice of crystal growth has played a central role in creating our current information and digital age as evidenced by the breakthroughs enabled by bulk growth of single crystal silicon, strained silicon-germanium epitaxy and III-nitride heteroepitaxy, to name a few. 

 The ACCGE-23/OMVPE-21 played an important role in supporting and sustaining the field of crystal growth in the U.S. Symposium topics included concepts related to the fundamentals of materials synthesis (thermodynamics, transport phenomena, kinetics), crystal structure (defects, characterization methods), techniques (solution growth, epitaxy, vapor phase deposition, bulk growth), manufacturing (high throughput processing, in situ monitoring, process modeling) and specialized topics (2D materials, textured ceramics, ferroelectrics, microfluidic processing). 

Broader Impact

ACCGE-23/OMVPE-21 provided professional development opportunities for graduate students and early career researchers to present the results of their research and interact with a larger network of professionals in the crystal growth field. A career panel event was held for students to introduce them to the diversity of careers in the crystal growth field. Proceedings from the conference were published in the Journal of Crystal Growth. A photo contest was held to allow participants to share compelling scientific and artistic images arising from their research.  Additional social activities during coffee breaks promoted engagement of participants within the virtual platform.

The ACCGE conference has historically had substantial participation from crystal growth practitioners in industry both as attendees and organizers.  Consequently, several technical sessions were devoted to issues relevant to manufacturing and commercialization of bulk crystals and epitaxial thin films including topics such as process modeling and scale-up, in situ monitoring and characterization and equipment design for high throughput processing. The substantial industry involvement in the meeting provided graduate student attendees with exposure to industry-relevant problems in manufacturing and opportunities to network and learn about career opportunities.
